awd_titl_txt: Electrochemical Separation and Recovery of Metals from Liquid Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
The research made possible by this award will explore faster, safer, and more sustainable methods of precious metal recycling. This will guide researchers toward understanding the science behind the processing of materials. By virtue of its higher productivity, this new method can be utilized to the benefit of the US manufacturing economy. Precious metals have seen an increased prevalence in electronics; unfortunately, these devices have short lifetimes as they are quickly discarded for newer models. This grant supports investigation of a new method for metal recycling, called electrometallurgy, which makes use of electric fields to separate and recycle metals from scrap. This approach provides substantial benefits over existing methods for metal separation, which involve combustion or harsh acid dissolution. This fundamental research will investigate how electricity can be used to selectively recycle and purify the many different metals contained in electronic waste, targeting the precious metals (gold and silver). Bringing together the fields of processing science, thermodynamics, chemical engineering, and electrochemistry, this cross-disciplinary work will bring new knowledge of benefit to engineers in multiple fields. The basic principles developed can be extended to the sustainable production of metals for aerospace and defense, construction, and technology, presenting a large benefit to the US economy as well as public health. Furthermore, the computational tools developed in this work will be made widely available as free teaching tools for thermodynamics. This online tool will reach a broad and diverse audience, empowering students to pursue science and engineering. 

When compared to other recycling methods, electrometallurgy has the potential to reduce the energy use by 80x and the time needed for recycling by a factor of 10. In order to realize these benefits, however, the electrochemistry of liquid alloy electrodes must be better understood in order to be able to control which metal, among the many present in electronic waste (e-waste), is recycled. Furthermore, a high-temperature solvent, the first of its kind able to accommodate molten gold, copper, and silver simultaneously, will be investigated. This research aims to understand the underlying kinetic, transport, and thermodynamic factors that determine which species is reduced at the cathode and oxidized at the anode made of melted e-waste. A new model predicting which metals are stable and in what proportions will be developed. In addition, the rate-limiting step in the process will be verified with experimental electrochemical measurements. Advanced electrochemical characterization techniques, such as alternating current cyclic voltammetry, alongside traditional chronoamperometry and electromotive force measurements, will be employed experimentally. Mutiphysics modeling, thermodynamic calculations, and phase diagram predictions will be used to iterate and optimize process conditions on the computational side. Together, both experimental and modeling techniques will inform the underlying fundamentals of electrochemical behavior of molten precious metals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to investigate an alternative method of precious metals recycling that is both more efficient and environmentally friendly than the existing processes. This method, electrometallurgy, utilizes electricity to separate each metal while avoiding the harsh acids in hydrometallurgical routes or the heavy emissions in pyrometallurgical routes. The project studied study the fundamental reactions occurring inside an electrochemical cell, with the aim of being able to predict which metal is reduced first, and what conditions are necessary to maximize product purity. 

At first, thermodynamic models for the components of such electrochemical process - the cathode and the electrolyte - were developed. Those were based on prior thermodynamic data, for systems where prior experimental findings were available. The results of the model for such systems were then used to ombine both the cathode and the electrolyte model in order to represent more faithfully the engineering reality. A new model was then devised in order to take into account specificities of the "all-liquid" electrochemical approach considered therein. The new model was tested with prior nickel and cobalt electrodeposition results and rare-earth metal deposition. The limits of the model were identified, mostly related to process operating conditions where mass-transport (the bulk transport of species) in the electrolyte become important. The new model has been presented in several conferences and published in a peer-reviewed, archival journal.

In a second time, the model was used in a predictive manner for a new electrochemical reactor that extract copper and iron from sulfides. Therein, the model was able to predict the actual purity of the copper or iron deposits, and trends in their variation with the composition of the bulk electrolyte. This finding was instrumental in the choice of operating conditions of an electrochemical reactor at the kilogram scale, where each experiment requires about a week of work of multiple people, cost several thousands of dollars in materials. The approach, validated at such large-scale, proposes a faster establishment and validation of the operating windows and anticipated performanes of such processes. Those results also support a better evaluation of the productivity and energy consumption of processes. The results were presented at the world leading conference on Copper in 2022, and published in a peer-reviewed, archival journal.

In a third time, new, unstudied electrochemical systems were investigated. The separation of silver from copper in molten sulfides was demonstrated experimentally, modelled and validated with the model, allowing to highlight the differences and analogies with the Cu-Fe systems studied previously. The findings have been presented in several conferences and published in a peer-reviewed, archival journal. The results were also use to generate preliminary results toward the possibility to separate the rare-earth elements and niobium/tantalum using a molten sulfide electrolytes, approaches which are currently under continutal developments.

This project partially supported 2 graduate (PhD) students and one post-doc who got trained and devised advanced chemical metallurgy methods for the design of electrochemical and metallurgical processes, essential for the future of materials production in a sustainable manner. The methods comprise computing and experimental approaches . Those students themselves had the opportunity to teach thermodynamic and electrochemistry to their peer, or other students via classroom or lab experiences. In particular, several models have been devised for the teaching of electrodeposition thermodynamic for undergraduate and graduate students.
